    Development and Therapeutic Implications of Selective Histone Deacetylase 6 Inhibitors

    • Jay H. Kalin*
      •  and 
    • Joel A. Bergman
    View Author Information
    Department of Medicinal Chemistry and Pharmacognosy, University of Illinois at Chicago, 833 S. Wood Street, Chicago, Illinois 60612, United States
    *Present address: Department of Pharmacology, Johns Hopkins University, 725 N. Wolfe Street, Baltimore, MD 21205. Phone: (410) 614-0322. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2013, 56, 16, 6297–6313
    Publication Date (Web):April 29, 2013

    Publication History

    • Received31 January 2013
    • Published online15 May 2013
    • Published inissue 22 August 2013
    https://doi.org/10.1021/jm4001659
    Copyright © 2013 American Chemical Society

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    This Perspective provides an in depth look at the numerous disease states in which histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6) has been implicated. The physiological pathways, protein–protein interactions, and non-histone substrates relating to different pathological conditions are discussed with regard to HDAC6. Furthermore, the compounds and methods used to modulate HDAC6 activity are profiled. The latter half of this Perspective analyzes reported HDAC6 selective inhibitors in terms of structure, potency, and selectivity over the other HDAC isoforms with the intent of providing a comprehensive overview of the molecular tools available. Potential obstacles and future directions of HDAC6 research are also presented.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Pharmacological targeting of proteins that regulate epigenetics has emerged as a promising therapeutic area of study.(1-3) Two broad spectrum histone deacetylase inhibitors (HDACi), vorinostat (SAHA) and romidepsin (FK228), have already been approved for the treatment of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, further supporting the utility of inhibiting proteins responsible for chromatin remodeling (Figure 1).(4, 5) There are 11 unique Zn2+ dependent histone deacetylase (HDAC) isoforms that can be grouped into three classes depending on their sequence homology. Class I comprises isoforms 1, 2, 3, and 8. Class II can be further subdivided into class IIa, which includes isoforms 4, 5, 7, and 9, and class IIb, which is made up of isoforms 6 and 10. HDAC11 is the sole member of class IV and shares sequence similarities with both class I and class II HDACs. The sirtuins (SIRT1–7) constitute the class III HDACs and utilize NAD+ as a cofactor as opposed to zinc.(6) Their structural features, known substrates, and physiological roles have been reviewed elsewhere.(7-9) The focus of this Perspective is centered on the targeting of one isoform in particular, histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6), and the clinical benefits that may arise from altering the function of this protein.
    While nonselective inhibition of the HDAC isoforms has proven to be useful for the treatment of cancer, the inhibition of specific classes or isoforms has not yet yielded a clinical success. Throughout this Perspective, class selective refers to HDACi that target two or more isoforms in a particular class whereas isoform selective refers to compounds that are, ideally, selective for only one HDAC.(6) While a few class I selective inhibitors such as entinostat (MS-275) and mocetinostat (MGCD0103) have entered into the clinic, none of them have been approved by the FDA (Figure 2, clinicaltrials.gov: entinostat and mocetinostat). It has been reported that there are intrinsic toxic side effects associated with inhibition of the class I isoforms and that this prevents the application of broad spectrum and class I selective inhibitors to areas outside of oncology because of a small therapeutic window.(10-14) That being said, there are also reports indicating that class I HDACi could be useful for treating neurodegenerative conditions.(15, 16) In addition, clinical data related to class II selective HDACi are lacking, and therefore, our understanding of the associated toxicology is limited and could potentially be biased. Nevertheless, inhibition of the class II HDAC isoforms does not appear to be associated with the same level of toxicity observed with inhibition of the class I isoforms, suggesting that selective inhibition may provide a way to circumvent toxicity issues.(13, 17) Furthermore, there are an increasing number of reports in the literature indicating that HDAC6 expression and function are altered in a variety of disease states. The implications of this aberrant regulation are discussed in this Perspective.
    HDAC6 was first identified and characterized as a tubulin deacetylase.(18, 19) It is known to be primarily cytoplasmic and functions to deacetylate a plethora of other non-histone substrates in addition to α-tubulin.(20-23) However, HDAC6 has been observed in the nucleus under certain conditions and was found to colocalize with ligand-dependent corepressor (LCoR) in the nuclear compartment of estrogen-responsive MCF-7 cells.(24-26) Therefore, while HDAC6 may act primarily on nonepigenetic targets located in the cytoplasm, it may also be involved in epigenetic regulation as evidenced by its ability to repress the transactivation of estrogen-inducible reporter genes in breast cancer cells.(24)
    HDAC6 is a unique isoform in that it contains two independently functioning deacetylase domains and a C-terminal zinc finger domain responsible for binding ubiquitinated proteins.(18, 27-29) The large number of non-histone substrates allows HDAC6 to assume roles in multiple pathways within the cell, making its potential therapeutic implications difficult to discern. Furthermore, α-tubulin acetylation is often used as a biomarker for HDAC6 inhibition; however, it should not be assumed that this is always related to the observed biological activity.(30-39) Nevertheless, research describing the role of HDAC6 in specific disease states continues to be reported. The majority of these reports focus on the role of HDAC6 in autoimmune disorders and neurodegenerative diseases and as an anticancer agent, alone or in combination with other approved drugs.(2, 3, 40, 41) Thus, HDAC6 represents a valid target for further investigation regarding potential therapeutic applications. This Perspective summarizes the contemporary research being done on HDAC6 in relation to both the biological pathways involved and the pharmacological attempts to target it.

    Therapeutic Mechanisms

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Oncology

    While there have been a limited number of clinical trials involving the use of HDAC6 selective inhibitors, there has been an increasing number of reports in the literature implicating the selective inhibition of HDAC6 as a viable target for the treatment of a variety of solid and hematological malignancies (Figure 3).(42, 43) Examples of these cancers include lymphoma, leukemia, and myeloma in regard to hematological tumors and breast, lung, liver, prostate, bladder, and colon cancer, as well as melanomas, in regard to solid tumors. In addition, the antitumor effect observed via HDAC6 inhibition has been hypothesized to result through multiple mechanisms involving cell motility/migration, invasion, angiogenesis, induction of apoptosis, and inhibition of DNA repair.(25, 44-50) The ensuing section of this Perspective highlights some of the recent discoveries and advancements made relating to HDAC6 and its role in cancer development and progression.

    Multiple Myeloma

    Combination therapy constitutes an attractive approach to cancer chemotherapy, as drug synergism leads to lower therapeutic doses and helps to reduce toxicity resulting from off-target interactions, ultimately improving patient prognosis. An early combination approach identified a synergistic effect between tubacin and bortezomib, a proteasome inhibitor, for the treatment of multiple myeloma (MM) (Figure 4).(51) Tubacin treatment alone was found to inhibit MM cell growth in the low micromolar range (5–20 μM), even for drug-resistant MM cell lines, without inherent cytotoxicity to peripheral blood mononuclear cells. Presumably, this reduced toxicity is an advantage of selective isoform inhibition compared to broad spectrum HDAC inhibition. Unfortunately, MM cells can confer a mode of resistance by adhering to bone marrow stromal cells.(52) Strikingly, this combination strategy proved to be effective against this mechanism of resistance in MM and gave significance to anti-MM therapy of this nature for translation into a clinical setting.
    While there have been more than 300 clinical trials involving the use of broad spectrum and class I selective HDACi, oriented mostly toward oncologic applications, only two phase 1/2 clinical trials utilizing an isoform selective HDACi have been proposed, and they are still in the process of recruiting participants. These trials involve the use of a novel HDAC6 selective small molecule developed by Acetylon Pharmaceuticals, rocilinostat (ACY-1215), in combination with dexamethasone and either bortezomib or lenalidomide, a small molecule thalidomide derivative, for the treatment of MM (Figure 5). Bortezomib and lenalidomide have been approved for the treatment of MM in the United States. However, while rocilinostat may be considered HDAC6 selective, it is only moderately so with 12-, 10-, 11-, and 21-fold selectivity for HDAC6 over class I isoforms 1, 2, 3, and 8, respectively.(45) Nevertheless, rocilinostat was shown to significantly increase the level of acetylated α-tubulin compared to acetylated histone H3 and H4 in vitro. In addition, rocilinostat was reported to act synergistically with bortezomib in the treatment of MM both in vitro and in vivo. While not fully understood, one potential mechanism for the synergistic activity may be that simultaneous inhibition of the proteasomal machinery and aggresomal degradation pathway overwhelms the cell’s ability to deal with misfolded proteins, eventually triggering apoptosis.(45) Interestingly, when designing HDAC inhibitors to treat cancer, it may be desirable to be less selective to exploit the cytotoxicity associated with inhibiting the class I isoforms while simultaneously augmenting their activity by also targeting HDAC6.

    Breast and Ovarian Cancer

    Multiple reports have demonstrated that HDAC6 is required for cancer cell migration and invasion, particularly in relation to its α-tubulin and cortactin deacetylase activity.(46, 54, 55) In R2d cells, an estrogen responsive breast epithelial cell line, HDAC6 was necessary for migration and invasion during the process of endothelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT), a hallmark of metastatic cancer. Furthermore, it was demonstrated that overexpression of HDAC6 resulted upon exposure to phthalates, which are known endocrine disruptors, and facilitated the development of lung metastases in nude mice.(55) In the breast adenocarcinoma cell line MDA-MB-231, HDAC6 was shown to be necessary for proteolytic degradation of the extracellular matrix, facilitating cancer cell invasion. HDAC6 knockdowns, achieved using either siRNA or the small molecule trichostatin A (TSA), a broad spectrum HDACi, significantly reduced the ability of cancer cells to invade a surrounding collagen matrix.(46) Subsequent investigation led to the discovery that the dynamic regulation of α-tubulin and cortactin acetylation is important for cancer cell invasion.(47) Matrix metalloproteinase MT1-MMP was identified as a key component in the cancer cell invasion process; however, to function, it must be transported to the cell membrane. Cortactin hypoacetylation has been shown to facilitate association with actin filaments, which are key components of these membrane-associated, matrix-degrading cellular protrusions.(32, 44) Tubulin acetylation has been found to mediate intracellular trafficking and control focal adhesion during cell migration; however, the exact physiological mechanisms regarding how α-tubulin hypoacetylation facilitates cellular motility remain to be determined.(39, 56, 57)
    A report by Bazzaro et al. found that HDAC6 expression was significantly up-regulated in both low- and high-grade ovarian carcinomas compared to levels observed in benign lesions.(58) The authors suggested that this was likely due to increased levels of proteasomal stress in ovarian cancer and demonstrated selective cytotoxicity of a small molecule HDAC6 inhibitor, compound 1 (NK84, structure not disclosed), toward ovarian cancer cells as opposed to immortalized ovarian surface epithelial cells.(58, 59) Furthermore, a synergistic effect was demonstrated using compound 1 and the proteasome inhibitor, bortezomib, which lends additional support to the hypothesis that selective HDAC6 inhibitors induce cytotoxicity by disrupting the ability of cells to clear misfolded proteins.(58)

    Bladder Cancer

    Similar to what has been observed with breast cancer, HDAC6 has also been shown to potentiate migration and invasion in bladder cancer through a cortactin dependent mechanism.(48) Treatment with the HDAC6 selective inhibitor tubacin attenuated this process, suggesting that HDAC6 inhibitors may be useful for preventing cancer cell metastasis (Figure 4).

    Prostate Cancer

    There is some evidence suggesting that sulforaphane, a naturally occurring HDAC inhibitor commonly found in cruciferous vegetables, may provide chemopreventive and antiproliferative effects in prostate cancer (Figure 6).(60-62) These effects were found to be related to the non-histone HDAC6 substrate heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90). Inhibition of HDAC6 induces hyperacetylation of Hsp90, a molecular chaperone, which destabilizes the interaction between Hsp90 and the androgen receptor (AR), a well-known prostate cancer signaling agent that is often targeted for both treatment and prevention of the disease. In turn, destabilization of the AR leads to its degradation via the proteasome and subsequently decreases AR signaling and reduces AR associated gene expression.(60) These effects were demonstrated using sulforaphane and HDAC6 siRNA and abrogated when HDAC6 was overexpressed, suggesting that sulforaphane acts through an HDAC6 dependent mechanism.(60) While sulforaphane is not an extremely potent HDAC6 inhibitor, chronic exposure through consumption of foods containing it may provide some chemopreventive benefits.
    Similar to what was observed with MM, an additive effect was seen with treatment of tubacin in prostate cancer cell lines in combination with DNA damaging agents. The down-regulation of HDAC6 was found to sensitize LNCaP cells to topoisomerase II inhibitors, etoposide and doxorubicin, as well as the pan-HDACi vorinostat.(63) Administration of tubacin plus either vorinostat or etoposide led to elevated levels of PARP, a marker of apoptosis. An increase in γH2AX, an early stage biomarker for DNA double-strand breakage, was also documented in the same study. While early experiments indicated that selective HDAC6 inhibitors lacked efficacy in solid tumors, some of which will be discussed below, these data suggest that HDAC6 may potentiate current anticancer therapies, thus providing a good rationale for translation of future, more druglike HDAC6 inhibitors into preclinical and ultimately clinical settings.

    Lung Cancer

    In addition to data supporting the use of HDAC6 inhibitors as cytotoxic anticancer agents, there are also reports suggesting that these compounds may be able to sensitize cancer cells to other known chemotherapeutics. For instance, in multiple non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines, depletion of HDAC6, either by knockdown or by pharmacologic inhibition with tubastatin A, increased sensitization to cisplatin, a first line treatment for NSCLC (Figure 7).(25) In addition to sensitization, H292 cell colony formation was attenuated and xenograft size was reduced in nude mice when HDAC6 was depleted. Interestingly, the authors also found that a small portion of the cytosolic HDAC6 pool was relocated to the nucleus following administration of DNA damaging agents, further supporting the idea that HDAC6 plays a role in DNA damage repair. Furthermore, an increase in expression of p53, a known tumor suppressor protein, and phosphorylated p53 was observed in HDAC6-deficient cells, suggesting that HDAC6 may regulate the function of certain kinases known to be involved in the p53 pathway. However, while p53 activation is a reasonable mechanism by which HDAC6 sensitizes tumor cells, a number of NSCLC cell lines possessing a p53 mutation or deletion were also affected, which indicates the potential involvement of multiple sensitization pathways.(25) Additional studies have found that cells deficient in HDAC6 were more susceptible to MEK inhibitors, further supporting the role of HDAC6 in mediating kinase activity.(64)

    Liver Cancer

    Interestingly, there are conflicting reports regarding the involvement of HDAC6 in the development and progression of hepatic cancers; however, they may not be mutually exclusive.(49, 65) Consistent with observations in other types of cancer, one group found that siRNA knockdown of HDAC6 correlated with decreased rates of invasion and metastasis in three hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell lines. In addition, the group also examined 70 resected tumors and found that 20% of them exhibited increased expression of HDAC6, which correlated with higher tumor grades, higher numbers of tumors, and increased tumor aggressiveness, suggesting that HDAC6 expression levels may serve as a biomarker for intrahepatic metastasis and poor prognosis.(49) However, another group looking at HDAC6 levels in liver cells from patients with HCC found that HDAC6 expression was decreased or completely undetectable in approximately 47% of patients compared to only 6% of control samples tested. Additionally, the 5-year overall survival rate was approximately 18% lower for patients with low HDAC6 expression compared to those with high HDAC6 expression. They went on to show that HDAC6 was acting as a tumor suppressor through the JNK-activated beclin-1 dependent pathway.(65) While these reports appear to be conflicting, the discrepancy may be resolved by considering that HDAC6 could exhibit opposite effects in different pathways. Additional experiments will be required to fully elucidate the physiological mechanisms involved.

    Melanoma, Colon Cancer, and Hematologic Malignancies

    Recently, inhibition of HDAC6 using a small molecule urea based inhibitor, nexturastat A, has been shown to inhibit cancer cell proliferation and facilitate apoptosis in B16 murine melanoma cells (Figure 8).(66) This is consistent with other reports suggesting that HDAC6 inhibition using either TSA or tubacin disrupts cell cycle progression, possibly by promoting the interaction between cell cycle regulators such as CYLD and acetylated microtubules.(50) In colon cancer cells, selective inhibition of HDAC6 with either vorinostat or tubacin indirectly resulted in the down-regulation of FLIP, an antiapoptotic protein, by causing increased acetylation of Ku70. This in turn disrupts the stabilizing interaction between FLIP and Ku70.(67) Other reports evaluating the effect of tubacin in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) demonstrated that inhibition of HDAC6 resulted in the accumulation of polyubiquitinated proteins and that alone was sufficient to induce apoptosis. They also demonstrated that combinatorial therapies with DNA damaging agents were beneficial for managing ALL both in vitro and in vivo.(68) Similar encouraging results were obtained with a selective HDAC6 inhibitor, compound 2 (ST80), in the treatment of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Figure 8).(69, 70) Lastly, combinatorial treatment of Burkitt lymphoma cells with bortezomib and tubacin synergistically enhanced apoptosis, possibly through a proteasome/aggresome dependent pathway.(71)

    Autoimmunity

    In addition to the anticancer effects of HDAC6 inhibition, there is also strong evidence supporting HDAC6 as a target for the treatment of numerous autoimmune disorders.(3, 72-74) Additionally, it has been demonstrated that pharmacologic inhibition of HDAC6 activity does not induce significant toxicity in vitro or in vivo.(10, 17, 75) HDAC6 has been shown to inhibit regulatory T cell (Treg) mediated immunosuppression, while inhibition of HDAC6 has been found to enhance Treg function and restore immune homeostasis.(76) In the succeeding section, implications of HDAC6 inhibition as they relate to certain autoimmune disorders are discussed.

    Colitis and Allograft Rejection

    In murine models, pan-HDACi, such as vorinostat and TSA, were able to alleviate the symptoms and reverse the progression of established colitis via a Foxp3+ Treg dependent pathway.(76) In addition, HDAC6 selective inhibitors such as tubacin and tubastatin A but not class I selective HDAC inhibitors such as entinostat were able to confer protection in these in vivo models, suggesting that it is HDAC class II inhibition that is responsible for the observed physiological response.(76, 77) Since HDAC class IIa proteins are generally thought to be catalytically inactive, these results suggest that the immunosuppressive effects are a result of class IIb HDAC inhibition, specifically HDAC6 inhibition per the results obtained using tubacin and tubastatin A.
    Upon observation that HDAC6 inhibition resulted in the enhancement of Treg mediated immunosuppression, interrogation of the involved molecular pathway was undertaken in murine models of allograft rejection.(76) One of the well characterized non-histone substrates of HDAC6 is the molecular chaperone Hsp90. The selective HDAC6 inhibitors tubacin and tubastatin A in combination with low-dose rapamycin, a clinically used immunosuppressant, were able to significantly increase the lifespan of mice from approximately 15 days to more than 60 days in comparison to mice treated with rapamycin alone. The same effect was observed when a small molecule Hsp90 inhibitor, 17-N-allylamino-17-demethoxygeldanamycin (17-AAG), was used in combination with low-dose rapamycin instead of an HDAC6 inhibitor, suggesting that Hsp90 is the relevant downstream target of HDAC6 in this model. It is important to note that this combination therapy was only administered for 14 days but was able to confer long-term protection against allograft rejection.(76)

    Neurodegenerative Disorders and Oxidative Stress

    HDACs have long been implicated in the development and progression of neurodegenerative disorders; however, the specific isoforms and molecular pathways involved have not yet been fully elucidated (Figure 9).(75, 78-80) Similar to the field of oncology, there are conflicting reports regarding inhibition of HDAC6 for the treatment of these diseases. Again, because of the large number of non-histone substrates, it is quite possible that inhibition of HDAC6 may be beneficial for one disease but detrimental in another.(40) Therefore, additional research will be necessary to determine the pathology associated with various neurodegenerative diseases and to identify the HDAC isoforms, if any, that are involved in each particular affliction. As it stands now, numerous reports exist suggesting that HDAC6 inhibition may be beneficial in protecting cells from oxidative stress-induced cell death, which may benefit patients afflicted with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), Parkinson’s disease (PD), and even inherited neurological disorders such as Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) and Rett syndrome. There is also mounting evidence suggesting that HDAC6 may play a beneficial role in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) through mediation of cellular autophagy.(26, 38, 39, 75, 80-85)

    Traumatic Brain Injury, Hypertension, and Stroke

    TBI often results in serious impairment of cognitive and motor functions and may even contribute to the development of other neurological disorders, including AD.(86) TBI can induce a number of significant pathologies; however, the inflammatory pathway in particular may be uniquely related to HDAC6.(76) TBI results in the release of extracellular cytokines that can ultimately lead to the activation of microglia and their transformation to phagocytes, which can further complicate recovery from TBI.(82) The moderately HDAC6 selective mercaptoacetamide based HDACi, compound 3 (DMA-PB), significantly inhibited microglial transformation and reduced neuronal degradation when administered shortly after lateral fluid percussion injury in rats (Figure 10).(10, 82)
    The development of therapies with sufficient efficacy to treat patients suffering from ischemic stroke is a major challenge in the field of neurobiology.(81) Following the initial event, increases in levels of extracellular excitatory amino acids, free radical production, and inflammation have been observed.(87, 88) While broad spectrum HDAC inhibitors have been reported to provide some therapeutic benefits, the therapeutic window available for treatment was low because of the intrinsic cytotoxicity associated with inhibiting the class I HDAC isoforms.(79, 89, 90) A study by Chen et al. found that HDAC3, -6, and -11 were significantly up-regulated in murine models of ischemic stroke.(81) Using an oxygen and glucose deprivation model, they went on to show that shRNA knockdown of HDAC3 and HDAC6 significantly improved the survival rate of cortical neurons in culture. With regard to HDAC6, the mechanism by which its inhibition confers neuroprotection in ischemic stroke is still under investigation.(81) However, it has been reported that HDAC6 inhibition results in the hyperacetylation of peroxiredoxin-1 and -2 leading to increased resistance against oxidative stress such as that observed during ischemic stroke.(38)
    Similarly, broad spectrum HDAC inhibitors have demonstrated beneficial effects in the treatment of cardiac hypertension.(91, 92) Mechanistically, these broad spectrum HDAC inhibitors were shown to prevent cardiac hypertrophy, fibrosis, and inflammation in murine models.(93-96) They were also shown to prevent left ventricle hypertrophy in rats susceptible to inducible, chronic hypertension.(97) A paper by Lemon et al. found that HDAC6 was significantly up-regulated in the heart as a result of spontaneous hypertensive heart failure and hypoxia induced hypertrophy.(98) While the exact therapeutic mechanism is unknown, this study highlights the need for additional experiments to determine if there could be any therapeutic benefit related to HDAC6 inhibition in the heart.

    Charcot–Marie–Tooth Disease

    In 2011, the van den Bosch lab reported on the curative effect of HDAC6 selective inhibition using tubastatin A in murine models of CMT, the most common inherited neurodegenerative disorder of the peripheral nervous system.(39) They found that transgenic mice exhibiting mutations in the small heat shock protein (HSPB1, also known as Hsp27) presented a phenotype consistent with that observed for distal hereditary motor neuropathy (distal HMN). Interestingly, these mice exhibited decreased levels of acetylated α-tubulin, and axonal transport of mitochondria was severely impaired. HDAC6 is known to function as an α-tubulin deacetylase and to affect intracellular trafficking; thus, the phenotype implicated HDAC6 as potentially being involved with this disease.(35, 99, 100)
    Axonal transport of mitochondria is crucial for maintaining energy homeostasis, as distances between the cell body and neurites may be quite large in some instances.(101) This necessitates energy production closer to where it will be consumed, and thus, mitochondrial transport along axons and dendrites is crucial for maintaining proper neuronal functioning. Intracellular trafficking is dependent on molecular motors such as dynein and kinesin-1, which bind to acetylated α-tubulin, indicating HDAC6 as a viable drug target.(35, 39, 100-102) In addition, there are reports suggesting that HDAC6 is necessary for maintaining mitochondrial metabolic homeostasis.(103) Indeed, treatment of dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons from the transgenic mice described above with TSA, tubacin, or tubastatin A restored acetylated α-tubulin levels and consequently the observable number of moving mitochondria. The two HDAC6 selective inhibitors tubacin and tubastatin A were more effective than TSA in this model. Furthermore, in vivo treatment with tubastatin A significantly increased motor function and corrected the electrophysiological defects observed with these transgenic mice. Lastly, treatment with tubastatin A decreased the level of denervation observed in the neuromuscular junctions, and preliminary results suggest that tubastatin A may be able to induce reinnervation of muscles, effectively reversing the phenotype observed with this disease.(39) Thus, HDAC6 has emerged as a very promising drug target for the treatment of CMT and potentially for other peripheral neuropathies in which axonal transport deficiencies are a causative factor.(104)

    Autophagy

    HDAC6, as previously mentioned, acts as a cortactin deacetylase and serves to modulate the process of cellular autophagy.(105, 106) HDAC6 is recruited to ubiquitinated proteins that are targeted for degradation. Upon recruitment, HDAC6 subsequently enrolls F-actin remodeling machinery via a cortactin-dependent mechanism, which stimulates autophagosome fusion to lysosomes, the organelles that carry the molecular machinery required for controlled protein degradation. This process of controlled protein degradation, referred to as quality control autophagy, is distinct from starvation induced autophagy where cells nonselectively degrade cellular proteins and organelles for energy in a time of dire need.(107) Importantly, the involvement of HDAC6 has been identified as one of the crucial distinguishing factors between the two types of autophagy such that HDAC6 promotes the fusion of proteins and organelles tagged for destruction to the lysosome whereas starvation induced autophagy is nonselective and does not require HDAC6 for autophagosome–lysosome fusion.(105)
    The importance of clearing cellular debris and misfolded proteins is well established and has been demonstrated in mouse models.(108, 109) The accumulation of these junk proteins and nonfunctional organelles will eventually lead to cytotoxicity and neurodegeneration as evidenced in mice and Drosophila.(105) In these models, retardation of HDAC6 activity via either knockdown or knockout experiments resulted in ubiquitin-labeled protein aggregate formation and neurotoxicity. The lack of HDAC6, however, did not prevent autophagy activation but rather autophagosome–lysosome fusion, suggesting that this process may be important in the progression of neurodegenerative conditions such as AD. Furthermore, studies have identified increased levels of autophagic structures in brain tissue of AD patients, suggesting that there may be a defect in their clearance, possibly a result of impaired autophagosome–lysosome fusion.(85) The modulation of autophagy by HDAC6 may also have implications in PD.(84) Parkin, a protein that if mutated causes PD, is responsible for ubiquitinating nonfunctional mitochondria. As described above, HDAC6 is recruited to these ubiquitinated mitochondrial proteins and facilitates mitophagy, a term referring to the autophagic degradation of mitochondria. Thus, the development of pharmacologic agents that facilitate this process may be therapeutically relevant to the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.(110)

    Alzheimer’s Disease

    Consistently regarded as one of the most devastating and widespread neurodegenerative disorders, AD continues to be a condition that refuses to yield to pharmacological intervention. While there are numerous hypotheses regarding its etiology, none have emerged as undisputable. Therefore, continued efforts into determining the underlying cause and potential therapeutic avenues of treatment are of paramount importance. Researchers at the Mayo Clinic recently identified HDAC6 as having a role in regulating tau homeostasis.(83) Aberrant tau phosphorylation and clearance are known to play a role in a number of neurodegenerative diseases, collectively referred to as tauopathies, including frontotemporal dementia, progressive supranuclear palsy, and corticobasal degeneration, in addition to AD.(111, 112) Tau degradation was reportedly mediated through interaction with the ubiquitin ligase carboxy terminus of Hsp70-interacting protein, CHIP, and Hsp90.(113-116) CHIP and Hsp90 are required for tau ubiquitination and proper folding, respectively. Thus, if either protein is not functioning properly, tau homeostasis may be disrupted, eventually leading to the formation of neurofibrillary tangles. Knockdown of HDAC6 by siRNA has been shown to induce Hsp90 hyperacetylation, subsequently resulting in decreased affinity of Hsp90 for client proteins, including tau, which ultimately results in their degradation as opposed to refolding.(23, 117, 118) Furthermore, Cook et al. found that in addition to ubiquitinating misfolded and aberrantly phosphorylated tau, CHIP was able to ubiquitinate HDAC6 leading to its degradation and the consequent hyperacetylation of Hsp90.(83) Decreasing levels of CHIP both in vitro and in vivo resulted in increased levels of HDAC6 that ultimately had detrimental effects on tau levels. Lastly, inhibitors of Hsp90 are known to bind more tightly when Hsp90 is hyperacetylated, suggesting that inhibition of HDAC6 and Hsp90 may be synergistic in nature.(119, 120) The devastation caused by AD, in terms of both quality of life and the financial burden resulting from care, warrants further investigation into the role of HDAC6 in the development and progression of this disease.
    The other leading hypothesis regarding the development of AD involves the deposition of amyloid plaques as a result of amyloid precursor protein (APP) processing by β- and γ-secretase, ultimately culminating in the production of neurotoxic peptides.(121) A group at Georgetown recently reported on the development of two novel HDACi, a mercaptoacetamide, compound 4 (W2), originally synthesized by Kozikowski et al., and a hydroxamic acid, compound 5 (I2) (Figure 11).(10, 122-124) They evaluated these compounds in vitro and found that compound 4, a class II selective compound, was more effective at reducing amyloid β (Aβ) levels compared to compound 5, a class I and class II HDAC inhibitor. On the basis of these results, they further evaluated the effect of compound 4 in transgenic AD mice and found that this compound was able to significantly reduce both soluble and insoluble levels of Aβ.(26) Among the potential mechanisms of action identified, the authors hypothesize that disruption of the interaction between a protein responsible for processing the mRNA transcripts of β-secretase 1(BACE1), heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein H (hnRNP H), and HDAC proteins leads to decreased levels of β-secretase and subsequently lower levels of Aβ.(26) However, compound 4 is reported as a class II selective HDACi and the class II HDACs are primarily cytosolic, whereas hnRNP H is a nuclear protein. Therefore, unless HDAC6 is translocated to the nucleus, it is unlikely that this process is mediated by class II HDAC inhibition.(25)
    Interestingly, a recent report suggests an alternative way in which HDAC6 inhibition may alleviate the deleterious effects associated with Aβ.(125) One of the well-known substrates of HDAC6 is α-tubulin, which is a major component of microtubules.(126) Post-translational modification (PTM) of tubulin is intimately involved in the stability of microtubules, and this PTM status mediates axon guidance, synapse formation, and neuronal transport.(39, 102, 127-129) Aβ is known to alter microtubule stability and intracellular signaling pathways, which leads to defects in vesicular and axonal transport.(130, 131) The loss of proper axonal transport leads to synaptic degradation through impaired mitochondrial and neurotransmitter trafficking.(130, 132) Kim et al. demonstrated that treatment of neurons with Aβ oligomers significantly attenuated mitochondrial elongation and transport, which was subsequently alleviated by treatment with the HDAC6 inhibitor tubastatin A.(125) These results suggest that HDAC6 inhibition may slow or reverse the neuronal damage associated with Aβ and thus represents a viable drug target for the treatment of AD.

    Development of Selective HDAC6 Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As a potential limit to the rational design of isoform selective inhibitors, the HDAC isoforms are highly homologous across the Zn2+ dependent classes I, II, and IV.(7, 133) Despite this apparent similarity, sequence alignments show that there are subtle differences that can be utilized by small molecule inhibitors to impart selectivity.(8, 9, 53, 133) By better understanding the pharmacophore for potent and selective HDAC6 inhibition, smaller, more druglike compounds can be made, validated, and hopefully advanced to the clinic.

    Broad Institute, Harvard University

    As evidence supporting the therapeutic benefit of modulating HDAC6 activity continues to grow, its targeted and selective inhibition proves more attractive. The first significant small molecule HDAC6i came from a diversity oriented synthetic (DOS) approach from Schreiber and co-workers.(19) A 7392-membered library was screened and revealed tubacin, an HDAC6 selective inhibitor adhering to the canonical HDAC inhibitor scaffold and capable of inducing elevated levels of acetylated α-tubulin (Figures 4). The molecular structure of tubacin displays three distinct components that comprise the archetypal HDACi: zinc-binding group (ZBG), linker, and cap motifs (Figure 12). While tubacin shares an identical ZBG and linker with vorinostat, a pan-HDACi, the intricate cap group is able to impart selective HDAC6 inhibition (Figure 12). Unlike TSA, which modifies the acetylation state of chromatin barrels, tubacin was unable to alter gene expression or cell cycle progression, further confirming that the major substrates for HDAC6 are non-histone proteins as opposed to chromatin and gene transcription modifiers. As tubacin was the first significant HDAC6 selective inhibitor identified, it has been used extensively as a chemical tool. Some of these uses were previously discussed in this Perspective. Following the development of tubacin, Bradner et al. reported on the use of the previously mentioned HDAC6 selective inhibitor rocilinostat and its use in combination with either bortezomib or lenalidomide for the treatment of MM (Figure 5).(45)

    University of Illinois at Chicago

    Tubacin relies primarily on interactions with the surface of the different isoforms for its high selectivity (Figure 12). However, in addition to surface recognition motifs, other features were soon discovered to play a role in isoform tuning. Here, the ZBG was a key contributing factor for selective HDAC6 inhibition. Kozikowski and co-workers modified the traditional hydroxamic acid ZBG to a mercaptoacetamide resulting in a more selective HDAC6 inhibitor, compound 6 (Figure 13).(10) It was found that only the mercaptoacetamide analogues were nontoxic to cortical neurons and, moreover, were capable of offering dose-dependent protection in a model of oxidative stress induced by homocysteic acid (HCA). Additionally, these sulfur-containing ZBG analogues were unable to increase acetylated histone H4 levels as detected by Western Blot analysis, further demonstrating their HDAC6 selectivity in vitro. Continued evaluation of the mercaptoacetamide ZBG, exemplified by compounds 3 (MA-2) and 6 (MA-1), demonstrated that selective pharmacologic inhibition of HDAC6 led to protection against oxidative stress-induced neurodegeneration and promoted neurite outgrowth (Figures 10 and 13).(75) Furthermore, the mercaptoacetamide compound 4 was capable of both decreasing Aβ mRNA levels while increasing Aβ clearance in vitro (Figure 11).(26) Moving into an in vivo system, the authors saw a significant decrease in soluble and insoluble Aβ levels in hAPP 3xTg AD mice. These data point to the utility of thiols as potent and selective ZBGs for HDAC6 inhibitor development and a possible new avenue for treatment of AD.
    The biphenyl hydroxamic acid and mercaptoacetamide series were further developed, and structure–activity relationship (SAR) investigations included modifying the biphenyl to a phenylthiazole, compounds 7 and 8 (Figure 14).(10, 134) These compounds were evaluated across a panel of pancreatic cancer cell lines where several of them were found to exhibit significant antiproliferative activity. However, the most potent were bereft of selectivity compared to HDAC1 and the more HDAC6 selective analogues displayed reduced potency suggesting that the anticancer properties of these compounds may not have been due to HDAC6 inhibition.
    The use of nitrile oxide cycloaddition (NOC) chemistry was reported by Kozikowski and co-workers to assemble potent HDACi that contained an aryl substituted isoxazole cap (Figure 15).(135) This synthesis was straightforward and amenable to library production. Some of these compounds displayed a preference in isoform selectivity, and compound 9 was more potent than vorinostat in the pancreatic tumor cell panel. These analogues all maintained the alkyl linker motif, but while potent inhibitors of HDAC3 and HDAC6 resulted, they possessed nanomolar activity against other isoforms. Because of the submicromolar activity against HDAC1, it cannot be ruled out that the antiproliferative activity observed may have been a result of off-target HDAC effects.
    Incorporating similar chemistry, the isoxazole motif was next installed within the linker region, leading to compounds that did not possess simple alkyl linkers.(136) It was proposed that the imposed rigidity may induce isoform selectivity. In addition, this new aryl group adjacent to the ZBG, when combined with potent cap groups, provided the avenue for researchers to develop compound 10 (Figure 15). However, this design resulted in reduced potency toward HDAC6 compared to the parent alkyl-containing compounds; furthermore, a decrease in potency in a panel of pancreatic cancer cells was observed, demonstrating that this demarcation from an alkyl linker was not favored.
    More recently, Kalin et al. synthesized a series of analogues that possessed the isoxazole cap but introduced a chiral mercaptoacetamide center to further elaborate on the SAR of this ZBG.(137) The lead compound 11, which lacked the chiral ZBG, possessed submicromolar activity at HDAC6 (IC50 of 260 nM) and yet had modest selectivity (HDAC1 IC50 of 5.7 μM) (Figure 16). The most favorable substitution was the introduction of an α-methyl group, and only the (R)-enantiomer, compound 12, was capable of HDAC6 inhibitory activity with a modest IC50 of 280 nM for HDAC6. Substitution at this position provided excellent selectivity across the other isoforms evaluated (Figure 16). As seen with previous mercaptoacetamides (vide supra), this chiral ZBG analogue was able to protect against HCA-induced oxidative stress. Docking the chiral analogues into the active site of an HDAC6 homology model revealed that the (R)-enantiomer was able to achieve bidentate zinc chelation whereas the (S)-enantiomer was not, thus confirming the empirical data obtained.
    In the same manner as seen with the isoxazole library generated above, a series of triazole-containing cap groups was synthesized.(138) Again, the triazole motif allowed for facile library synthesis for the purpose of identifying cap groups that demonstrated favorable interactions with the unique structural variations present in the different isoforms, thus leading to potentially selective and potent agents. Both regioisomers of the 1,2,3-triazole derivatives were synthesized, and it was found that the triazole motif and its substitution afforded less impact on HDAC6 inhibition compared to the attachment point of the central phenyl motif, compounds 13–15 (Figure 17). As seen previously for the isoxazole-capped HDAC inhibitors, the triazole variety also possessed pancreatic cancer cell toxicity and interestingly also showed antimalarial activity even against several resistant strains.(134, 138) While a mechanism for this new activity remains unclear, the possibility for new antimalarial compounds under the guise of nontoxic HDAC6 inhibitors remains a promising approach.
    A significant advancement in the development of druglike small molecules that were both potent and selective HDAC6 inhibitors was reported by Butler et al., resulting from rational design using a homology model of HDAC6. Construction of the homology model demonstrated significant topology differences at the entrance to the catalytic site that were unique to HDAC6.(53) One difference observed was a drastically reduced length in the tunnel connecting the surface and the catalytic site compared to distances for solved HDAC crystal structures. Additionally, a wider entrance to this tunnel opening was envisioned to allow for larger and bulkier cap groups that could potentially serve to improve selectivity. Combining these two parameters, SAR studies concluded that a tricyclic carboline cap together with a benzyl linker, which was best suited in length, resulted in tubastatin A, a small molecule HDAC6 inhibitor with an IC50 of 15 nM and >1000-fold selectivity over HDAC1 (Figure 7). Tubastatin A displayed the characteristic in vitro acetylation preference for increasing acetylated α-tubulin but not acetylated histone levels.(53) Moreover, it offered neuroprotection to cortical neurons in a model of HCA-induced oxidative stress, the first hydroxamic acid based HDAC inhibitor to do so, suggesting that neurotoxicity is associated with class I activity as opposed to being an inherent characteristic of hydroxamic acids.(53)
    Building on the information gleaned from the development of tubastatin A, three series of substituted β- and γ-carbolines were synthesized to further develop the SAR for the tricyclic series of HDAC6 selective inhibitors.(139) Substitutions to the 6-, 7-, 8- and 9-positions of the γ-carboline derivatives, exemplified by compound 16, resulted in compounds with similar potencies toward HDAC6 but significantly reduced selectivity over HDAC1 compared to tubastatin A (Figure 18). However, substitution of the nitrogen atom in the 2-position of both the β- and γ-carbolines, as exemplified by compounds 17–19, resulted in significantly improved potency toward HDAC6 and selectivity over HDAC1 (Figure 18). Similar to tubastatin A, these compounds suppressed Treg mediated immune responses, further supporting their application in the treatment of autoimmune disorders.(76, 139) To date, these compounds remain the most potent, selective, and druglike HDAC6 inhibitors reported.
    The work to elucidate the pharmacophore of tubastatin A revealed the benzyl linker as an important motif for generating first-pass HDAC6 selectivity.(53, 139) Early SAR investigations suggested that steric bulk also played a major role in exerting its potent and selective inhibitory activity. To further this assertion, a series of simple arylurea capped analogues were synthesized and, as expected, found to lack isoform selectivity. However, inclusion of a branched linker motif, typified in nexturastat A, increased both potency and selectivity for HDAC6 with an IC50 of 5 nM at HDAC6 compared to 3 μM at HDAC1 (Figure 8).(66) SAR data indicated that hydrophobic appendages were best suited for optimal activity. The benzyl motif has thus emerged as a significant contributor to potent and selective HDAC6 inhibitors. Interestingly, nexturastat A displayed improved inhibition of B16 melanoma cell growth, which correlated with in vitro HDAC6 activity.(66)

    Wayne State University

    An early approach toward the investigation of isoform selectivity was aimed at modifying analogues of vorinostat. Because modifications of the cap groups resulting in pan-HDAC inhibitors were well established in the literature, Pflum and co-workers sought to evaluate analogues of vorinostat with appendages at the C2- and C3-positions, with the goal to determine if selectivity could be achieved through interactions of the enzyme with the linker motif (Figure 19).(140, 141) Initially, a series of C2-substituted vorinostat analogues was synthesized, and it was soon discovered that modifications at this position were detrimental for HDAC inhibition, as the most potent C2-substitution, compound 20, resulted in 800-fold reduction in HDAC inhibition compared to vorinostat.(140) Moreover, there was no indication of isoform selectivity. Compounds incorporating substitutions at the C3-position were also synthesized yielding inhibitors that exhibited moderate selectivity for HDAC6.(141) Substitutions at this position resulted in compounds that were more potent than the C2 variants. In particular, the C3-ethyl analogue, compound 21, was modestly potent (IC50 of 8 μM) vs HDAC6 and had ∼3- and ∼10-fold selectivity over HDAC1 and HDAC3, respectively (Figure 19).

    University of Freiburg

    HDACi design from the Jung laboratory investigated modifications to the cap and linker groups and utilized molecular modeling to facilitate understanding of the requirements for HDAC6 isoform selectivity. This work was built around the framework of phenylalanine-HDAC inhibitors developed in their lab that possessed antiproliferative activity.(142) This work resulted in two chemicals, compounds 22 and 23, that possessed 10- and 13-fold selectivity for HDAC6 and HDAC1, respectively (Figure 20).(143) As to be expected, the most selective HDAC6 inhibitor displayed the least amount of cytotoxicity as measured by cell proliferation assays in a panel of cancer cell lines. However, the implication is similar to that of tubacin such that these compounds may offer synergistic activities when used as a combination therapy.(51, 143)
    The SAR data from the above compounds were further developed with a small set of pyridylalanine analogues.(144) Interestingly, the authors reported that the stereochemistry (R- vs S-) at the cap provided little influence in selectivity (Figure 20). Utilizing homology models to guide their efforts, the authors determined that the aryl cap was better suited for achieving interactions with the surface of HDAC6 vs HDAC1 as a hypothesis for the observed selectivity. Meanwhile, increasing the alkyl linker led to reduced selectivity for HDAC6 vs HDAC1 (attributed to increasing HDAC1 potency). The pyridylalanine derivative (R)-24 resulted in low micromolar HDAC6 activity (IC50 of 4 μM; selectivity vs HDAC1, ∼20-fold) that possessed little antiproliferative activity against MCF-7 cells; however, it displayed synergistic activity with bortezomib. The (S)-enantiomer of the pyridylalanine derivative, compound (S)-24, displayed similar activity toward HDAC6 but reduced selectivity over HDAC1 (Figure 20). These data further refine the notion that modifying the length of the linker has implications in directing isoform selectivity.

    Nagoya City University

    Suzuki and co-workers described the synthesis and biochemical evaluation of a series of non-hydroxamate HDACi.(145-147) Interestingly, a thiol ZBG analogue was quite potent in their initial screen, and inclusion of this motif resulted in potent HDAC inhibition. However, there was no indication regarding selectivity, though it stands to reason that there would be none based on the cap and linker motifs used. These findings were then incorporated into a “substrate-based” approach that came from the Jung laboratory where isoform selective substrates were identified.(148) The idea was to utilize a cap that would be selective for the surface of HDAC isoforms with the thiol ZBG. Unfortunately, this hybrid design did not display the desired selectivity; however, SAR investigations revealed that replacing the aromatic cap with a cycloheptyl group, compound 25, resulted in a compound possessing an IC50 of 23 nM for HDAC6 with 39- and 37-fold selectivity versus HDAC1 and HDAC4, respectively (Figure 21).(149)

    MethylGene Inc

    Pharmaceutical companies have also demonstrated interest in the development of selective HDAC6 inhibitors. Chiral cap groups synthesized by Smil and co-workers resulted in unique compounds with selectivity for HDAC6.(150) Not surprisingly, the stereochemistry of the 3,4-dihydroquinoxalin-1(2H)-one cap group played a major role in biochemical activity where the (R)-analogue, compound (R)-26, displayed approximately 20-fold selectivity for HDAC6 vs HDAC1 whereas the (S)-analogue, compound (S)-26, was much less potent and selective (Figure 22). Similarly, compound (R)-26 selectively induced elevated levels of α-tubulin in a dose-dependent manner, signifying that analogues of this type are bona fide HDAC6 inhibitors.

    Medical University of South Carolina

    Recently, an effort to uncover new pharmacophores for HDAC inhibition was undertaken. Undoubtedly, the desire to enter into new chemical space for HDAC6 inhibitor design was a prime motivating factor. Chou and co-workers utilized high-throughput screening of the LOPAC library to identify compounds with HDAC inhibitory activity.(151) This screening identified a naphthoquinone structure with promising activity, which they followed up by synthesizing several vitamin K analogues for further evaluation. Interestingly, compound 27 (NQN-1) demonstrated modest HDAC6 inhibition in the micromolar range and also increased acetylated α-tubulin levels (Figure 23). Moreover, compound 27 displayed low micromolar anti-AML activity. Despite possessing a highly problematic Michael acceptor as the core pharmacophore, it was found to be largely nontoxic, only inhibiting the proliferation of activated peripheral blood mononuclear cells. The authors went on to suggest that the anti-AML activity of compound 27 could be attributed to modulation of the acetylation state of Hsp90 and subsequent inhibition of the proteasomal pathway. Compound 27 remains a modestly selective HDAC6 inhibitor, but an exact mechanism for its HDAC6 inhibition remains unclear, especially because it does not possess the canonical ZBG.

    Cellzome AG

    The powerful methodology of chemoproteomics was recently applied in an attempt to develop an understanding of the complex roles of HDACs, in association with other proteins and with HDAC inhibitors.(152) The authors used a matrix-anchored HDAC inhibitor in combination with free ligand and were able to measure binding affinities of large multiprotein complexes in what may be a more apropos reflection of the cellular context. The authors were able to assemble a variety of HDAC beads to ascertain how the specific HDAC inhibitors interact across the epigenome and beyond, revealing interesting new avenues for research. Extending the utility of their approach, they modified their experimental HTS setup to identify potential new HDAC inhibitors and discovered a new activity for bufexamac, a known NSAID (Figure 24). Bufexamac was found to bind HDAC6 with a Kdapp of 10 μM (and also a Kdapp of 12.3 μM for HDAC10) without any significant activity against the other isoforms tested. While bufexamac is not an exceedingly potent HDAC6 inhibitor, the usefulness of such an investigatory platform may be of great utility in future endeavors to discover the role of specific HDAC6 inhibitors in a cellular context.

    Merck

    Another approach for the development of selective class II HDAC inhibitors was accomplished using a library screen biased with known metal chelation motifs. Emerging from the screen was a trifluoroacetylthiophene ZBG-linker system (Figure 25).(153) Not surprisingly, the hydrated form of these compounds was the active species, and while the authors were interested in HDAC4 selective inhibitors (class IIa), there was little discernible difference in activity for HDAC6 (class IIb). When evaluated in cells, only compound 28 was capable of producing selective increases in levels of acetylated α-tubulin vs acetylated histone H3. The other compounds in the series displayed no response (Figure 25).(153) The efforts were continued, and analogues were synthesized that removed the amide linkage, resulting in a direct aryl–aryl motif for the linker-cap region and yielded compounds with improved selectivity for HDAC6, exemplified by compound 29 (Figure 25).(154) Electron withdrawing groups generally favored HDAC inhibition in vitro as well as cellular stability (determined using HCT116 cells). These observations were generalized by the authors to suggest that improved electron withdrawing properties of the cap and linker facilitated trifluoroacetyl hydration, leading to more efficient activation of the ZBG and simultaneously preventing cellular reduction to an inactive species. Several active analogues were able to selectively increase acetylated α-tubulin levels but were not efficacious as cytotoxic agents in cancer cells.(154)

    Perspective

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    While it is well established that inhibitors of the class I HDACs are useful in the treatment of cancer, inhibitors selective for a single isoform or the class II HDACs have yet to be successfully applied in the clinic (clinicaltrials.gov: approved HDACi, vorinostat and romidepsin; HDAC6i, rocilinostat). The lack of selective inhibitors has made it difficult to elucidate the specific functions of individual isoforms, and therefore, it has been difficult to identify their unique physiological roles. While interfering RNA is quite useful, it significantly reduces the protein concentration inside the cell. Thus, in addition to inhibiting catalytic activity, protein–protein interactions and protein complexes will also be disrupted. However, numerous advancements regarding isoform selective inhibitors have been made over the past few years, including the development of selective HDAC6 inhibitors, that have augmented our understanding of HDAC isoform biology.
    With regard to HDAC6, there are three very general therapeutic areas that appear to be most susceptible to alterations in HDAC6 activity. These are autoimmune disorders, neurodegenerative diseases, and certain types of cancer. The advantage of using HDAC6 inhibitors for the treatment of autoimmune disorders and neurodegenerative conditions has been recognized for some time. The fact that HDAC6 inhibitors do not seem to be cytotoxic toward normal cells is encouraging for treating diseases outside the field of oncology. Both autoimmune and neurodegenerative diseases require a wider therapeutic window compared to cancer; thus, this lack of intrinsic toxicity is essential. Furthermore, the preclinical results are very encouraging. As described above, selective pharmacological inhibition of HDAC6 led to curative results in mouse models of colitis and CMT and significantly improved survival rates in mice with cardiac allografts. These results may ultimately pave the way for clinical trials using these selective HDAC6 agents.
    There has also been a significant amount of interest with regard to the role of HDAC6 in cancer. Originally, HDAC6 selective inhibitors were found not to provide the same level of efficacy as pan-HDAC inhibitors and were thus considered inferior for this application. However, more recent reports have suggested that HDAC6 inhibitors may provide excellent results when used in combination with other known drugs. Indeed, the HDAC6 inhibitor previously mentioned, rocilinostat, is currently being clinically investigated in combination with either bortezomib or lenalidomide for the treatment of MM. Furthermore, it may be beneficial to fine-tune an HDAC inhibitor to have activity at both HDAC6 and the class I HDACs to exploit the anticancer effects of class I HDAC inhibition while simultaneously taking advantage of the synergistic effect resulting from HDAC6 targeting. Additionally, HDAC6 inhibition may sensitize cells to other cytotoxic therapies that target protein folding/processing pathways and could lead to safer therapies by lowering the necessary dose of the cytotoxic agent.
    It is the opinion of these authors that the most promising clinical applications of selective HDAC6 inhibitors will involve combinations with other drugs. Because the HDAC family of proteins is involved in so many different cellular processes, off-target activity may limit their use as monotherapies. However, because of the large amount of positive preclinical data, their monotherapeutic uses should continue to be investigated. Lastly, it is important for HDAC inhibitors to be druglike. Thus, the continued investigation into the design and development of novel HDAC6 agents is warranted. The availability of noncanonical HDAC6 inhibitors and compounds with better pharmacokinetic profiles will be paramount to the future success of the field.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    This Perspective provides an overview of the state-of-the-art regarding the use of selective HDAC6 inhibitors for the treatment of a myriad of diseases ranging from cancer to autoimmunity to neurodegeneration. We examined the biochemical pathways relating HDAC6 modulation to disease etiology and treatment to summarize some of the major non-histone substrates and proteins that associate with HDAC6. Furthermore, we presented evidence to support the pharmacological targeting of HDAC6 to treat these diseases. Lastly, we reviewed the literature for published compounds reported to be HDAC6 selective and provided their activities at all isoforms tested. Future success regarding the development of selective HDAC6 inhibitors as clinical candidates will rely on a better understanding of how HDAC6 functions in the cell and the continuing efforts to tailor the activity, selectivity, and pharmacokinetics of these compounds.

    ARTICLE SECTIONS

    Abbreviations Used

    HDACi

    histone deacetylase inhibitor(s)

    vorinostat

    suberoylanilide hydroxamic acid

    HDAC

    histone deacetylase

    HDAC6

    histone deacetylase 6

    MM

    multiple myeloma

    EMT

    endothelial to mesenchymal transition

    TSA

    trichostatin A

    Hsp90

    heat shock protein 90

    AR

    androgen receptor

    NSCLC

    non-small-cell lung cancer

    ALL

    acute lymphoblastic leukemia

    AML

    acute myelogenous leukemia

    Treg

    regulatory T cell

    TBI

    traumatic brain injury

    PD

    Parkinson’s disease

    CMT

    Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease

    AD

    Alzheimer’s disease

    HSPB1

    small heat shock protein (also referred to as Hsp27 (heat shock protein 27))

    HMN

    hereditary motor neuropathy

    DRG

    dorsal root ganglion

    APP

    amyloid precursor protein

    Aβ

    amyloid β

    BACE1

    β-secretase 1

    hnRNP H

    heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein H

    PTM

    post-translational modification

    DOS

    diversity oriented synthesis

    ZBG

    zinc-binding group

    HCA

    homocysteic acid

    structure–activity relationship

    NOC

    nitrile–oxide cycloaddition

      The role of epigenetic mechanisms and processes in autoimmune disorders
      Greer, Judith M.; McCombe, Pamela A.
      Biologics: Targets & Therapy (2012), 6 (), 307-327CODEN: BTTICT; ISSN:1177-5491. (Dove Medical Press Ltd.)
      A review. The lack of complete concordance of autoimmune disease in identical twins suggests that nongenetic factors play a major role in detg. disease susceptibility. In this review, we consider how epigenetic mechanisms could affect the immune system and effector mechanisms in autoimmunity and/or the target organ of autoimmunity and thus affect the development of autoimmune diseases. We also consider the types of stimuli that lead to epigenetic modifications and how these relate to the epidemiol. of autoimmune diseases and the biol. pathways operative in different autoimmune diseases. Increasing our knowledge of these epigenetic mechanisms and processes will increase the prospects for controlling or preventing autoimmune diseases in the future through the use of drugs that target the epigenetic pathways.

    6. 6
      Bieliauskas, A. V.; Pflum, M. K. Isoform-selective histone deacetylase inhibitors Chem. Soc. Rev. 2008, 37, 1402– 1413
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Isoform-selective histone deacetylase inhibitors
      Bieliauskas, Anton V.; Pflum, Mary Kay H.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2008), 37 (7), 1402-1413CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Histone deacetylase (HDAC) proteins are transcription regulators linked to cancer. As a result, multiple small mol. HDAC inhibitors are in various phases of clin. trials as anti-cancer drugs. The majority of HDAC inhibitors non-selectively influence the activities of eleven human HDAC isoforms, which are divided into distinct classes. This tutorial review focuses on the recent progress toward the identification of class-selective and isoform-selective HDAC inhibitors. The emerging trends suggest that subtle differences in the active sites of the HDAC isoforms can be exploited to dictate selectivity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXnsFejsbs%253D&md5=326e20da0623a00114f43e5c459c9920
    7. 7
      de Ruijter, A. J.; van Gennip, A. H.; Caron, H. N.; Kemp, S.; van Kuilenburg, A. B. Histone deacetylases (HDACs): characterization of the classical HDAC family Biochem. J. 2003, 370, 737– 749
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Histone deacetylases (HDACs): characterization of the classical HDAC family
      de Ruijter, Annemieke J. M.; van Gennip, Albert H.; Caron, Huib N.; Kemp, Stephan; van Kuilenburg, Andre B. P.
      Biochemical Journal (2003), 370 (3), 737-749CODEN: BIJOAK; ISSN:0264-6021. (Portland Press Ltd.)
      A review, with refs. Transcriptional regulation in eukaryotes occurs within a chromatin setting, and is strongly influenced by the post-translational modification of histones, the building blocks of chromatin, such as methylation, phosphorylation and acetylation. Acetylation is probably the best understood of these modifications: hyperacetylation leads to an increase in the expression of particular genes, and hypoacetylation has the opposite effect. Many studies have identified several large, multisubunit enzyme complexes that are responsible for the targeted deacetylation of histones. The aim of this review is to give a comprehensive overview of the structure, function and tissue distribution of members of the classical histone deacetylase (HDAC) family, in order to gain insight into the regulation of gene expression through HDAC activity. SAGE (serial anal. of gene expression) data show that HDACs are generally expressed in almost all tissues investigated. Surprisingly, no major differences were obsd. between the expression pattern in normal and malignant tissues. However, significant variation in HDAC expression was obsd. within tissue types. HDAC inhibitors have been shown to induce specific changes in gene expression and to influence a variety of other processes, including growth arrest, differentiation, cytotoxicity and induction of apoptosis. This challenging field has generated many fascinating results which will ultimately lead to a better understanding of the mechanism of gene transcription as a whole.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXhvFKiu7o%253D&md5=8a521cd3ddcf046b4b806ebf9f1476b4
    8. 8
      Bradner, J. E.; West, N.; Grachan, M. L.; Greenberg, E. F.; Haggarty, S. J.; Warnow, T.; Mazitschek, R. Chemical phylogenetics of histone deacetylases Nat. Chem. Biol. 2010, 6, 238– 243
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Chemical phylogenetics of histone deacetylases
      Bradner, James E.; West, Nathan; Grachan, Melissa L.; Greenberg, Edward F.; Haggarty, Stephen J.; Warnow, Tandy; Mazitschek, Ralph
      Nature Chemical Biology (2010), 6 (3), 238-243CODEN: NCBABT; ISSN:1552-4450. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The broad study of histone deacetylases in chem., biol. and medicine relies on tool compds. to derive mechanistic insights. A phylogenetic anal. of class I and II histone deacetylases (HDACs) as targets of a comprehensive, structurally diverse panel of inhibitors revealed unexpected isoform selectivity even among compds. widely perceived as nonselective. The synthesis and study of a focused library of cinnamic hydroxamates allowed the identification of, to our knowledge, the first nonselective HDAC inhibitor. These data will guide a more informed use of HDAC inhibitors as chem. probes and therapeutic agents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhs1OmsLY%253D&md5=4f23cb8a5e3fb4090ead9eaa8b992c4a
    9. 9
      Butler, K. V.; Kozikowski, A. P. Chemical origins of isoform selectivity in histone deacetylase inhibitors Curr. Pharm. Des. 2008, 14, 505– 528
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Chemical origins of isoform selectivity in histone deacetylase inhibitors
      Butler, Kyle V.; Kozikowski, Alan P.
      Current Pharmaceutical Design (2008), 14 (6), 505-528CODEN: CPDEFP; ISSN:1381-6128. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Histones undergo extensive posttranslational modifications that affect gene expression. Acetylation is a key histone modification that is primarily regulated by two enzymes, one of which is histone deacetylase (HDAC). The activity of HDAC causes transcriptional silencing of DNA. Eleven distinct zinc-dependent histone deacetylase isoforms have been identified in humans. Each isoform has a unique structure and function, and regulates a unique set of genes. HDAC is responsible for the regulation of many genes involved in cancer cell proliferation, and it has been implicated in the pathogenesis of many neurol. conditions. HDAC inhibitors are known to be very effective anti-cancer agents, and research has shown them to be potential treatments for many other conditions. Histone deacetylase inhibitors modify the expression of many genes, and it is possible that inhibition of one isoform could cause epigenetic changes that are beneficial to treatment of a disease, while inhibition of another isoform could cause contradictory changes. Selective HDAC inhibitors will be better able to avoid these types of situations than non-specific inhibitors, and may also be less toxic than pan-HDAC inhibitors. Many potent pan-HDAC inhibitors have already been developed, leaving the development of selective inhibitors at the forefront of HDAC drug development. Certain structural moieties may be added to HDAC inhibitors to give isoform selectivity, and these will be discussed in this review. This review will focus on the applications of selective HDAC inhibitors, inhibitors reported to show selectivity, and the relationship between inhibitor structure and selectivity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXksVGksbw%253D&md5=7cb09f53ee939192450879caec4821bf
    10. 10
      Kozikowski, A. P.; Chen, Y.; Gaysin, A.; Chen, B.; D’Annibale, M. A.; Suto, C. M.; Langley, B. C. Functional differences in epigenetic modulators—superiority of mercaptoacetamide-based histone deacetylase inhibitors relative to hydroxamates in cortical neuron neuroprotection studies J. Med. Chem. 2007, 50, 3054– 3061
      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar

L.; Lu, Y.; Tsai, L. H. Deregulation of HDAC1 by p25/Cdk5 in neurotoxicity Neuron 2008, 60, 803– 817

      Chen, Y.; He, R.; D’Annibale, M. A.; Langley, B.; Kozikowski, A. P. Studies of benzamide- and thiol-based histone deacetylase inhibitors in models of oxidative-stress-induced neuronal death: identification of some HDAC3-selective inhibitors ChemMedChem 2009, 4, 842– 852

      Best, J. D.; Carey, N. Epigenetic therapies for non-oncology indications Drug Discovery Today 2010, 15, 1008– 1014
